headline: Gov. Kemp picks new district attorney, State Court judge for Columbus area
author: Mark Rice
sentences: Besides Jackson and Temesgen, Kemp interviewed William Hocutt IV, a prosecutor who started in Troup County in 2006 and served as assistant district attorney here starting in 2010, and Terry, the chief assistant district attorney under Jones for the circuit since Kemp suspended Jones in October.

Temesgen, now with the law firm Huff, Powell and Bailey will succeed State Court Judge Ben Richardson, who will replace Superior Court Judge Ben Land when Land fills the vacancy on the Georgia Court of Appeals left by Judge Andrew Pinsons departure.

Jackson, a criminal defense attorney with the Columbus firm Hagler, Henderson, Jackson and Walters as well as a former assistant district attorney here, will succeed Mark Jones as the Chattahoochee Judicial Circuit district attorney.

Jackson told the L-E late Monday that he felt thankful and grateful? that the governor trusted him to take command of the district attorneys office, and he hopes to make positive changes? when he takes office, likely in a few weeks.

Along with the appointments of Land and Richardson, Kemp also appointed in February Columbus attorney John Martin to fill the Chattahoochee Judicial Circuit Superior Court vacancy left by Judge William Rumers retirement in August.

Jackson, who where his parents were teachers, said hes honored to serve as the chief prosecutor in the Chattahoochee Judicial Circuit that besides Muscogee County includes Harris, Chattahoochee, Talbot, Taylor and Marion.

Kemp appointed Pinson to the Supreme Court of Georgia, filling the vacancy created by the retirement of Chief Justice David E. Nahmias, who will leave the bench at the end of the 2022 court term in July.
Jones took office in January 2021 after defeating incumbent Julia Slater in the 2020 elections, but he served only 10 months before Kemp after an indictment on felony charges alleging misconduct.
He petitioned the Georgia Supreme Court on Jan. 27 to let him which he admitted is tantamount to disbarment.? Last week, the the voluntary surrender of his law license.

Stacey Jackson and Pete Temesgen reaction to appointments
Jackson will be the circuits first Black district attorney officially in the position.
No dates to swear Jackson and Temesgen into office have been set, Kemp spokeswoman Katie Byrd told the Ledger-Enquirer on Tuesday.
Sheneka Terry became the first Black woman to serve in that capacity when she was sworn in as acting DA in October.
Former prosecutor Pete Temesgen, now working in civil law, will be the new Muscogee County State Court judge.
Brian Kemp has selected two more Columbus lawyers to fill vacant positions in the local judicial system.
In his criminal defense work, he has represented clients whose cases still are pending.
sentenced him to one year in prison and four years on probation and fined him $1,000.
Kemp at least four district attorney finalists to replace Jones, all of them local.
Prominent local defense attorney Stacey Jackson will be the new district attorney.
A jury was deliberating when Jones decided Nov. 15 to plead guilty and resign.
Jones resigned in November after pleading guilty to misconduct in office.
Jackson said he will need time to close his private practice.
Jones is serving his sentence in a medium-security prison.
Temesgen was among them.
